item.title: Google's DeepMind AI group unveils health care ambitions
item.description:
Google's DeepMind AI group unveils health care ambitions

Google's DeepMind artificial intelligence (AI) group today unveiled a new industry-specific program called DeepMind Health. A new website for the division reveals that Google has been working with multiple health care organizations, including National Health Service and the Royal Free Hospital London in the United Kingdom.

item.title: Zero Gravity Solutions, Inc. Issued Patent for Its Commercial Product for Agriculture, BAM-FX™, by the United States Patent and Trademark Office
item.description:
Zero Gravity Solutions, Inc. Issued Patent for Its Commercial Product for Agriculture, BAM-FX™, by the United States Patent and Trademark Office

BOCA RATON, Fla.-(BUSINESS WIRE)-February 24, 2016- Zero Gravity Solutions, Inc.'s (ZGSI or the Company) (Pink Sheets: ZGSI), an agricultural biotechnology public company commercializing its technology derived from and designed for Space with significant applications on Earth, has previously announced the notification of approval for BAM-FX by the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO).

item.title: Captain401 raises $3.5M to help small businesses create employee retirement accounts
item.description:
Captain401 raises $3.5M to help small businesses create employee retirement accounts

Captain401 announced today that it has raised $3.5 million for its employee retirement platform. The round was led by SoftTech VC and included participation from SV Angel, CrunchFund, Slow Ventures, Susa Ventures, Soma Capital, FundersClub, legendary NFL quarterback Joe Montana, and others.

item.title: Twitter launches Fabric app for iOS and Android
item.description:
Twitter launches Fabric app for iOS and Android

Twitter today is announcing the availability of a mobile app for its Fabric mobile development toolkit. The app is immediately available on both iOS and Android. No longer will app developers need to rely on their desktops and laptops in order to check on the health of their apps, find out the number of monthly active users or the average length of users' sessions, or discover crashes affecting certain users.

item.title: How Target evolved from selling items to selling experiences
item.description:
How Target evolved from selling items to selling experiences

Rocking a red nightgown, red lips, and red nails, Gwen Stefani performed live as part of a four-minute marketing extravaganza last week during the Grammy's commercial break. The musical number was filled with subliminal red and white spheres, not as advertising per se, according to retailing giant Target, but to help give the audience what they wanted: music in all its glory.

item.title: Learn Everything about Sentiment Analysis using R
item.description:
Learn Everything about Sentiment Analysis using R

Today I will explain you how to create a basic Movie review engine based on the tweets by people using R. The implementation of the Review Engine will be as follows: Gets Tweets from Twitter Clean the data Create a Word Cloud Create a data dictionary Score each tweet.

item.title: Can You Put a Face to Big Data?
item.description:
Can You Put a Face to Big Data?

A version of this essay was originally published at Tech.pinions, a website dedicated to informed opinions, insight and perspective on the tech industry. One of the most popular buzzwords in tech is something called Big Data. However, trying to get a straight answer as to what Big Data is can be difficult.

item.title: Google's New AI Can Tell Where Your Photo Was Taken Without Using Geotags
item.description:
Google's New AI Can Tell Where Your Photo Was Taken Without Using Geotags

In case you didn't already feel like Google was a creepy stalker, its artificial intelligence tools are rapidly crossing over into uncanny. The latest one is PlaNet, a new deep-learning machine that specializes in figuring out where a photo was taken-using nothing but the image's pixels.
